message.text: Nice post ! Reflects my view on the job.

3 Steps to Building an Effective Regulatory Strategy


It can be very appealing to build a regulatory strategy starting from the regulations, the guidelines, and precedence. Regulatory scientists know the regulations, know how to read and interpret guidance documents, and to read FDA's Summary Basis of Approval documents. Often, though, this can falsely lead a regulatory person to take a position of "No. FDA will say No. FDA won't allow it."

Rather, I use a different approach in developing a regulatory strategy, a 3-tiered approach. 

Thinking of a triangle, the 1st tier, understanding the science, forms the base. This ties the regulatory strategy to the basic science (e.g., mechanism of action, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics) and grounds the regulatory strategy to the underlying clinical need(s) of the patients we serve. Understanding the science enables the Regulatory scientist to understand his/her functional colleagues and provide more relevant and appropriate regulatory guidance to the program team and to the organization.

The 2nd tier is understanding the clinical/business needs.  I typically start my consideration and evaluation of regulatory strategy from the perspective of the scientific/business need(s) simultaneously derived with the clinical strategy. The regulatory strategy has to be developed simultaneously with the technical strategy. In doing so, then, the 2 are always in sync and support eachother.

The 3rd, and top, tier is to define what is possible within the confines of regulations, guidances, precedence, etc. I have been surprised many times by what regulators are open to considering to potentially benefit patients, so I don’t restrict my regulatory strategy to only what I believe may agreeable to regulators. In preparing for meetings with regulators, I challenge my organization to ask “what’s possible." I approach interactions with regulatory authorities with that same question to find out “what’s possible” from a regulator perspective. My principal tactic in working with regulatory agencies is to map out the space within which my organization can operate, to find the boundaries of what’s possible based on direct feedback from regulators. I make a proposal to the regulators a "plan" that attempts to address the regulator’s needs while overlapping with the corporate strategy giving a win to both parties. In doing so, then, the regulators can do their job of (typically) narrowing the boundaries of what we have proposed. Once the “regulatory” boundaries are defined, then my organization goes off to solidify the final plan. 

Using this 3-tiered approach avoids the "starting with a no" position — “no, you can’t do that,” or “no, FDA will never agree to that.” Rather, defining a “what’s possible” approach provides the organization with flexibility as new data emerge, plans change, etc.  You know, normal drug development stuff!

Explore how CEO / C-suite synergy with Regulatory professionals can revolutionise your Life Sciences business. Feel free to comment with any additional thoughts on this important topic. #synergy #CEO #RegulatoryAffairs
